item.title: Contact
item.dc:creator: Admin
item.content:encoded:
If something on the Essentialist has resonated with you, donâ€™t hesitate to drop meÂ a message or give a call. Anything goes. And please tune in to the social pages to get all the news and updates. Cheers.

You can reach me at:

pavel@mauer.co +7 911 930 98 74

Follow on:

Facebook,Â Instagram,Â Twitter

item.title: Why I Decided to Stay in Brooklyn
item.dc:creator: Admin
item.content:encoded:
One day the landlord came to my Brooklyn home to do some small repairs. He was a senior black man with really nice manners, very calm and polite. The kind of person that gives you a feeling youâ€™ve learned something from them each time you meet.Â I was just starting my day late in the morning, wandering around the apartment enjoying the lazy minutes I could have before getting into something seriousÂ when he showed at the door â€” in his classy flat cap and a suit vest. [gallery ids="776,777,775,774"] We shared a little conversation, he asked meÂ what I was going to do that day. I told him I needed to go to Manhattan but havenâ€™t decided yet if I should do it that day or the next day.
â€œThereâ€™s something going on in Manhattan today, some big event. It may be hard getting around there. Better stay in Brooklyn todayâ€, he told me and continued repairing the ceiling.
I looked at his ideally ironed trousers and felt the absurd of him putting plaster on the ceiling wearing them. This way of approaching things was a significant part of this manâ€™s identity.Â I went to the fire escape to have a cigarette and kept mumbling â€œBetter stay in Brooklyn today. Better stay in Brooklyn.â€ Thatâ€™s what I did. These photos are the result.

item.title: A Road Trip Through the Desert
item.dc:creator: Admin
item.content:encoded:
On the first part of the journey IÂ was looking at all the life.Â There were plants and birds and rocks and things, there was sand and hills and rings. The first thing I met was a fly with a buzz and the sky with no clouds.Â The heat was hot and the ground was dry, but the air was full of sound.Â Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipisicing elit. item.title: The Boneyard
item.dc:creator: Admin
item.content:encoded:
Decommissioned planes are brought to this boneyard in Tucson, Arizona because of dry climate and hard desert soil. Itâ€™s easier to preserve the machines in dry air, and their wheels easily roll on the desert soil. Some of the planes come here to be modernized and get back into the air. Some become spare part donors. And some are recycled to get aluminium.
The metal in that can of soda you recently had â€” it could have been flying 30â€™000 feet (10 km) high in the sky a few years ago.
Seeing hundreds of giant mechanisms lost in an even more giant desert gives an incredible experience of silence that can be â€œseenâ€ in these photos. [gallery ids="776,777,775,774"] Fuga temporibus provident molestias culpa nostrum error cum ratione mollitia vero illum laudantium eos debitis quisquam recusandae, deserunt quam assumenda, accusamus odio.Â Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet, consectetur adipisicing elit. item.dc:creator: Admin
item.content:encoded:

item.title: Galleries Showcase
item.dc:creator: Admin
item.content:encoded:
You can create galleries like the ones you see belowÂ â€” using native WordPress gallery functionality. No custom shortcodes or buttons. Just the native galleries. Woohoo!
[gallery ids="777,775,774"]
Your photos' previews are formed into collages automatically. Look atÂ how neatly these 4Â images have stacked:
[gallery ids="776,777,774,775"]
The galleries have a fullscreen mode (lightbox) with captions and zoom. On mobile you can exit a lightbox by simply swiping up or down â€” that's what we've all got used to with the Facebook's mobile app.

item.title: A Crash Course in Color Grading
item.dc:creator: Admin
item.content:encoded:
Before digital photography has arrived, everybody was doing color grading no matter if they wanted it or not. Every film had its own character â€” and often these were artists who helped design each film's unique colors. That's why unprocessed digital photos often seem soulless and we often need to color grade them to achieve an artistic effect.
â€œThe chief function of color should be to serve expression.â€ â€” Henri Matisse

item.title: Responsive Video Embeds
item.dc:creator: Admin
item.content:encoded:
This theme feature responsive video embeds. VideosÂ you postÂ will keep the aspect ratio that was given to them by the video hosting at any screen size. Here is an example of a YouTube video:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FniPoPixipY
And here is a Vimeo video:
https://vimeo.com/136228343
To insert a video into a post or a page just paste a YouTube or Vimeo video url.

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: <iframe src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/136228343" width="1170" height="658" frameborder="0" title="Los Angeles" webkitallowfullscreen mozallowfullscreen allowfullscreen></iframe>

item.title: Chicago: Windy City Stories
item.dc:creator: Admin
item.content:encoded:
Try to feel the air of the â€œwindy cityâ€ pressing against your face. Many of Chicagoâ€™s folklore traditional genres are tied to historical events, characters, and places such as the Great Fire of 1871, Al Capone, Jane Addamsâ€™s Hull House, the steel mills of South Chicago and northwest Indiana, and Chicagoâ€™s swampy location at the base of Lake Michigan. Chicagoâ€™s unofficial neighborhood names often become official geographic markers such as Bronzeville, famous home of jazz andÂ blues musicians on the South Side, Maxwell Street, for the old market on Halsted Street (which has now been â€œofficiallyâ€ moved by the city to Canal Street), and such areas asÂ Little Italy, Chinatown, Greektown, and Little Vietnam, all named for the apparent majority of their residents.
"Let me tell your something. I'm from Chicago. I don't break." â€”Â Barack Obama
